org.apache.drill.exec.physical.impl.scan.v3.lifecycle

Class TestScanLifecycleTwoReaders

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.drill.test.BaseTest
      • org.apache.drill.test.DrillTest
        • org.apache.drill.test.SubOperatorTest
          • org.apache.drill.exec.physical.impl.scan.v3.lifecycle.BaseTestScanLifecycle
            • org.apache.drill.exec.physical.impl.scan.v3.lifecycle.TestScanLifecycleTwoReaders

  • public class TestScanLifecycleTwoReaders
extends BaseTestScanLifecycle
    Test two readers in succession in various cases: empty readers, normal readers, type conflicts, etc.

    • Method Detail

      • testTwoNullReaders

        public void testTwoNullReaders()
        Two null readers: neither provides a valid scan schema.

      • testNullThenValidReader

        public void testNullThenValidReader()

      • testValidThenNullReader

        public void testValidThenNullReader()

      • testTwoValidReaders

        public void testTwoValidReaders()

      • testShrinkingSchema

        public void testShrinkingSchema()
        SELECT * FROM two readers, one with (a, b), the other with just (a). The scan will reuse the type of b from the first reader when filling the missing column in the second reader. Since the schema shrinks, the result is the same whether schema change is allowed or not.

      • testShrinkingSchemaWithConflict

        public void testShrinkingSchemaWithConflict()
        Shrinking schema, as above. Explicit projection:
        
 SELECT a, b FROM (a) then (a,b)

        But choose a missing column type (the default Nullable INT) in the first reader that will conflict with the actual column type (VARCHAR) in the second.

      • testExpandingSchemaAllowingSchemaChange

        public void testExpandingSchemaAllowingSchemaChange()
        SELECT * FROM two readers, one (a, b), the other (a, b, c). With schema change enabled, the third column shows up only in the second batch, forcing a schema change downstream.

      • testExpandingSchemaDisallowingSchemaChange

        public void testExpandingSchemaDisallowingSchemaChange()
        SELECT * FROM two readers, one (a, b), the other (a, b, c). With schema change disabled, the third column is ignored in the second reader: the first reader "fixes" projection to just (a, b) even though projection started as wildcard.

        We can argue if this behavior is correct. We know most operators, and no ODBC or JDBC client can handle schema change. So, our other options are do the schema change anyway (the above test), fail, or this choice, which is to try to muddle though. The correct solution is to provide a schema (tested elsewhere.)

      • testEarlySchemaTypeConflict

        public void testEarlySchemaTypeConflict()
        SELECT * from two readers: both (a, b), but with a conflicting type for the column b. The reader fail will with a type conflict.

      • testLateSchemaTypeConflict

        public void testLateSchemaTypeConflict()
        SELECT * from two readers: both (a, b), but with a conflicting type for the column b. The reader fail will with a type conflict.

      • testModeConflict

        public void testModeConflict()
        SELECT * from two readers: both (a, b), but with a conflicting type for the column b. The reader fail will with a type conflict. We could possibly try to handle a NULLABLE --> NON NULLABLE conflict, but there does not yet appear to be a compelling case for doing so.

      • testColumnReorderingAB

        public void testColumnReorderingAB()
        SELECT * FROM (a, b) then (b,a). The order of the first table drives the order of the results.

      • testColumnReorderingBA

        public void testColumnReorderingBA()
        SELECT * FROM (b,a) then (a, b). The order of the first table drives the order of the results.

      • testSpecifiedColumnOrder

        public void testSpecifiedColumnOrder()
        SELECT , b FROM (b,a) then (a, b). The order of the project list drives the order of the results.
